prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Apollo Justice
Description: A lawyer who's been at the agency since before I joined. He has an amazing ability to spot lies through people's tells.
Character 1
Name: Phoenix Wright
Description: The lawyer who owns the agency. I owe him for giving me the chance to become a full-fledged lawyer.
Character 2
Name: Trucy Wright
Description: Mr. Wright's darling daughter. She wants to be a famous magician someday.
Character 3
Name: Aristotle Means
Description: A lawyer course professor at the academy. His smile is somewhat scary.
Character 4
Name: Constance Courte
Description: The professor who invited Mr. Wright to the academy. She is a judge course teacher, but she's not very punctual.
Character 5
Name: Juniper Woods
Description: A senior in the judge course. She's a good friend, and I've known her since childhood.
Character 6
Name: Hugh O'Conner
Description: A senior in the lawyer course who served as the defense in the mock trial. He seems like kind of a jerk.
Character 7
Name: Robin Newman
Description: A senior in the prosecutor course who served as the prosecution in the mock trial. He tends to shout at people.
Character 8
Name: Bobby Fulbright
Description: The lively detective in charge of this case. He makes you wonder what justice is really all about.
Character 9
Name: Simon Blackquill
Description: A prosecutor and prison inmate. He has mastered the use of psychological manipulation in courtroom battles.
Character 10
Name: Klavier Gavin
Description: Mr. Rock Star Prosecutor himself, he was the leader and vocalist of the Gavinners.
Character 11
Name: Myriam Scuttlebutt
Description: A senior in the judge course. She is the aloof editor-in-chief of the school paper who walks around with a box over her head.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: My brand-new, shiny badge. It shows that I'm a lawyer.
Evidence 1
Name: Arrow
Description: The arrow that pierced the victim's side. It's stained with blood.
Evidence 2
Name: Courte's Planner
Description: Constance Courte's planner. A sword emblem is printed on the cover and on each page.
Evidence 3
Name: Themis Herald
Description: A school paper with a malicious scoop on an alleged love triangle involving Junie.
Evidence 4
Name: Stage Costume
Description: A costume Junie was supposed to wear. It has a glowing star pattern. (With notes, 2 pages.)
Evidence 5
Name: Mock Trial Script
Description: A top secret script written by Junie. There's only one copy. (4 pages.)
Evidence 6
Name: Themis Herald Extra
Description: An extra edition of the school paper that covers the mock trial.
Evidence 7
Name: Awl
Description: The weapon used to murder Constance Courte. Her blood was found on it along with Junie's fingerprints.
Evidence 8
Name: Courte's Autopsy Report
Description: Est. time of death: Between 6 and 8 PM. Cause of death: Blood loss from a deep stab wound in the victim's side.
Evidence 9
Name: Tape Recorder
Description: Used by Myriam to secretly record the conversation in the art room. A woman can be heard shouting, "You're a goner!" A woman can be heard shouting, "You're a goner!" Recorded in the art room at 7:10 PM on the 23rd. The voice on the tape says "You're a goner!" just like in Junie's script. It may be a fake. The voice on the tape says "You're a goner!" just like in Junie's script. It's been identified as a fake. Identified as a fake. Prof. Means used Hugh to pass it on to the police.
Evidence 10
Name: Glowing Costume Photo
Description: A photo of the stage costume taken in a dark room. A coat of fluorescent paint made it glow.
Evidence 11
Name: School Camera Photo
Description: A photo of the art room while preparations were being made. Taken on the day of the murder.
Evidence 12
Name: School Banner
Description: A large banner that was hung by a wire between the stage and art room. A trace amount of blood was found on it.
Evidence 13
Name: Purple Fragment → Purple Fragments
Description: A purple fragment from a broken statue. It was found all alone in the strangest of places. Two purple fragments of a broken statue. Going to search for more. Three purple fragments of a broken statue that originally stood on a pedestal onstage.
Evidence 14
Name: White Fragment → White Fragments
Description: A large, white fragment. It has a distinctive shape that could be described as angular. Two large, white fragments. It looks like it would feel good to break them.
Evidence 15
Name: Lady Justice
Description: This and the statue of Klavier were broken at the same time, but have been repaired. No one knows where it came from. It was found broken onstage. Professor Courte had remade it into a completely different-looking statue the day before the mock trial.
Evidence 16
Name: "Hugh" Scrap
Description: Discovered onstage, it appears to be a piece of paper torn from a notebook. The name "Hugh" is written on it.
Evidence 17
Name: Burnt Fragments
Description: The burnt remnants of the Gavinners banner that was tossed into the incinerator and later found by Myriam.
Evidence 18
Name: Stage Set Up Photos
Description: The last two of Myriam's photos. They show the students setting up the stage's backdrop on the night of the murder. (2 photos.) [caption] There is a tall construction screen between the stage and the vantange point near the maintenance area. Two banners are lying on the stage. A person is watching the stage. Another person is making a sculpture on the stage.
Evidence 19
Name: Voiceprint Analysis
Description: The results of the voice analysis performed on the tape recording.
Evidence 20
Name: Lecture Hall Diagram
Description: A diagram of the lecture hall where the mock trial took place.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The Lecture Hall was packed before the mock trial, but the rest of the campus was empty.
Person: O'Conner
Testimony 1
Testimony: That's when I saw Juniper dragging a large mat from behind the stage.
Person: O'Conner
Testimony 2
Testimony: I was watching her from a vantage point between the stage and the maintenance area.
Person: O'Conner
Testimony 3
Testimony: She was heading towards me, so I assume she was on her way to the maintenance area.
Person: O'Conner
Testimony 4
Testimony: But I didn't have time to stand around and see what she did after that.
Person: O'Conner

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let's start by understanding the scenario. 

We have a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies related to a murder investigation at an academy. The key characters involved are Apollo Justice, Phoenix Wright, Juniper Woods, Hugh O'Conner, and others. The victim is Professor Constance Courte, and the main suspect seems to be Juniper Woods, a friend of the narrator.

Looking at the evidences, there's an arrow that pierced the victim's side, a planner belonging to Professor Courte, a stage costume Juniper was supposed to wear, and other items like the murder weapon (an awl), autopsy reports, and various photos and fragments.

Now, focusing on the testimonies provided by Hugh O'Conner:

1. He claims the Lecture Hall was packed before the mock trial, but the rest of the campus was empty.
2. He saw Juniper dragging a large mat from behind the stage.
3. He was watching her from a vantage point between the stage and the maintenance area.
4. He assumed she was heading towards the maintenance area.
5. He didn't have time to see what she did after that.

Next, I need to find an evidence that contradicts one of these testimonies. Let's go through the evidences one by one:

- **Evidence 0: Attorney's Badge** - Not relevant to the contradiction.
- **Evidence 1: Arrow** - The murder weapon, but doesn't directly contradict Hugh's testimony.
- **Evidence 2: Courte's Planner** - Shows she had a meeting with Hugh, which might relate to motive but not directly to the testimony about Juniper.
- **Evidence 3: Themis Herald** - A school paper with a scoop on Junie, possibly related to motive but not directly contradictory.
- **Evidence 4: Stage Costume** - Juniper's costume, which she was supposed to wear. Hugh mentions seeing her dragging a large mat, but if there's evidence about the costume, it might relate to her activities.
- **Evidence 5: Mock Trial Script** - Juniper's script, which includes the line "You're a goner!" matching the tape recording.
- **Evidence 6: Themis Herald Extra** - Covers the mock trial, not directly contradictory.
- **Evidence 7: Awl** - The murder weapon with Juniper's fingerprints, indicating she might have handled it, but Hugh's testimony is about her dragging a mat.
- **Evidence 8: Courte's Autopsy Report** - Details about the time and cause of death, which might conflict with timelines but not directly with Hugh's testimony.
- **Evidence 9: Tape Recorder** - The recorded voice threatening, which was faked, but Hugh's testimony is about Juniper's actions.
- **Evidence 10: Glowing Costume Photo** - Shows the costume glowing, which might be relevant if Hugh saw her wearing it.
- **Evidence 11: School Camera Photo** - Shows the art room during preparations, not directly contradictory.
- **Evidence 12: School Banner** - Blood on it, but Hugh's testimony is about Juniper's actions.
- **Evidence 13: Purple Fragments** - Broken statue fragments, possibly related to the crime scene but not directly to Hugh's testimony.
- **Evidence 14: White Fragments** - More fragments, same as above.
- **Evidence 15: Lady Justice** - Statue repaired, not directly related.
- **Evidence 16: "Hugh" Scrap** - A piece of paper with Hugh's name, indicating he might have been at the scene.
- **Evidence 17: Burnt Fragments** - Burnt banner remnants, not directly contradictory.
- **Evidence 18: Stage Set Up Photos** - Shows students setting up, including a person watching the stage and another making a sculpture. This might contradict Hugh's claim of the campus being empty.
- **Evidence 19: Voiceprint Analysis** - Confirms the tape was fake, not directly contradictory.
- **Evidence 20: Lecture Hall Diagram** - Layout of the hall, not directly contradictory.

Looking at **Evidence 18: Stage Set Up Photos**, it shows that there were people around, including someone watching the stage and another making a sculpture. This directly contradicts Hugh's testimony that the rest of the campus was empty. If there were people setting up and others around, Hugh's claim that the campus was empty except for the Lecture Hall is false.

Therefore, the contradiction lies between **Evidence 18** and **Testimony 0**.
</think>

cot:
Alright, so I've got this case to work on, and I need to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let's see what we've got here.

First, I'll go through the list of characters to get a sense of who's involved. There's Apollo Justice, the lawyer; Phoenix Wright, the owner of the agency; Trucy Wright, his daughter who wants to be a magician; and several professors and students at the academy. The victim is Constance Courte, a professor who was murdered.

Now, looking at the evidences, there's an arrow that was used to kill her, a planner belonging to the victim with a sword emblem, a school paper with a scoop on Juniper, a stage costume that Juniper was supposed to wear, and so on. There's also an awl with the victim's blood and Juniper's fingerprints, which seems pretty incriminating.

The testimonies include statements from Hugh O'Conner, Robin Newman, and Aristotle Means. Hugh says he saw Juniper dragging a large mat behind the stage, which makes me think she might have been moving something suspicious. Robin mentions that Juniper seemed nervous and kept looking at the clock, which could indicate she was worried about something. Professor Means claims Juniper confessed to the murder and asked him to protect her by pre-recording his speech.

Now, I need to find a contradiction between one of the evidences and one of the testimonies. Let's start by looking at the evidence that stands out the most: the awl with Juniper's fingerprints and the victim's blood. This directly links Juniper to the crime scene and the murder weapon.

Looking at the testimonies, Professor Means says Juniper confessed to the murder. However, if Juniper was indeed at the scene and handled the awl, her fingerprints would naturally be on it. But if she confessed, one might expect her to explain or provide an alibi, which she hasn't done here. This creates a contradiction because the physical evidence directly ties her to the crime, while her behavior, as described by Professor Means, suggests she was trying to cover something up.

Another angle is Hugh's testimony about seeing Juniper dragging a mat. If Juniper was moving something large, it could have been to hide evidence or the body. But the presence of her fingerprints on the awl suggests she was directly involved in the stabbing, not just moving things around.

Also, the stage costume with the glowing star pattern could be a red herring, but the fact that it was supposed to be worn by Juniper and was found with fluorescent paint might indicate she was near the crime scene, which aligns with Hugh's testimony.

However, the most direct contradiction seems to be between the physical evidence of the awl and Juniper's fingerprints, and Professor Means' testimony about her confession. The evidence places her at the scene and links her to the murder weapon, while the testimony suggests she tried to cover her tracks by involving Professor Means. This inconsistency is crucial because it questions the reliability of Professor Means' statement and highlights Juniper's potential guilt.

I should also consider the tape recorder evidence, which was identified as a fake. This could imply that someone tried to frame Juniper or create misleading evidence. If the tape was fake, it might have been used to mislead the investigation, which could explain why Juniper's fingerprints were found on the awl—perhaps she was framed.

But focusing back on the main contradiction, the awl with Juniper's fingerprints is a strong piece of evidence against her, while Professor Means' testimony about her confession adds another layer. If Juniper confessed, it would typically align with the physical evidence, but here it seems more like she's trying to manipulate the situation by involving Professor Means, which contradicts the straightforward implication of the evidence.

In conclusion, the evidence of the awl with Juniper's fingerprints directly ties her to the crime, while Professor Means' testimony about her confession introduces a conflicting narrative that doesn't fully align with the physical evidence, suggesting a contradiction.
</think>
